articleContent.title: Arpeggio: Dominant 7th in A
articleContent.content:
# Arpeggio: Dominant 7th in A

## Overview
An arpeggio is a musical technique where the notes of a chord are played one after the other instead of simultaneously. The Dominant 7th arpeggio in the key of A consists of the following notes: A (root), C# (major third), E (perfect fifth), and G (dominant seventh). 

## Notes and Intervals
- A (root) - 1st
- C# (major third) - 3rd
- E (perfect fifth) - 5th
- G (dominant seventh) - 7th

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The Dominant 7th arpeggio in A is commonly used in jazz, blues, funk, and rock music genres. It adds tension and flavor to chord progressions, leading naturally back to the tonic chord. The dominant 7th sound is often described as providing a sense of resolution and groove in the music.

## Songs
1. "Sweet Home Chicago" by Robert Johnson
2. "Blue Monk" by Thelonious Monk
3. "Superstition" by Stevie Wonder

Arpeggios are versatile musical tools that can add color and emotion to your playing. Experiment with integrating the Dominant 7th arpeggio in A into your music to explore its unique sound and feel.
